Authors: Chang-Hsin Kuo, Sung-Yuan Hsieh, Teik-Khiang Goh
Title:
Wenhsuisporus taiwanensis gen. et sp. nov., a peculiar setose
hyphomycete from submerged wood in Taiwan
Keywords:
Freshwater fungi, Glomerellales, lignicolous hyphomycetes,
Reticulascaceae, Sordariomycetes, phylogenetics, taxonomy
Abstract:
Wenhsuisporus taiwanensis gen. et sp. nov., a dematiaceous
hyphomycete occurring on decaying wood submerged in a freshwater stream
of Taiwan, is proposed based on morphological and molecular data. It
produces slimy masses of phialoconidia which are hyaline, cylindrical
and aseptate, from discrete conidiogenous cells arising from superficial
hyphal network associated with the swollen base of dark, erect, stiff,
unbranched subulate setae. The new genus is compared with similar
hyphomycete genera having setae or setiform conidiophores with phialidic
conidiogenous cells, such as Avesicladiella, Circinotrichum,
Cylindrotrichum, Gyrothrix and Kylindria. Phylogenetic relationship of
Wenhsuisporus was sought by comparing the sequences of its ITS, LSU and
RPB2 gene segments with those from representative taxa in the
Australiascaceae, Chaetosphaeriaceae, Glomerellaceae, Reticulascaceae,
Plectosphaerellaceae and Xylariaceae. Phylogenetic trees inferred from
concatenated sequences of these multilocus gene segments revealed the
placement of this new genus within the Sordariomycetes, closely related
to the Reticulascaceae of the Glomerellales. Since there is no other
known lineage with similar morphology or DNA sequences, the new genus
and species Wenhsuisporus taiwanensis is proposed.
